repository.corpname: M.E. Grenander Department of Special Collections & Archives

did.unittitle: Task Force for Long Range Planning Records1972-1973

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: State Univeristy of New York at Albany

did.abstract: Reports and memoranda from the commission established to determine the growth of SUNYA until the mid-1980s.
did.physloc: The materials are located onsite in the department.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Collection is maintained in the order it was acquired in.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Task Force for Long Range Planning was created as a group to evaluate the inner workings of the University and create plans to improve administration of various apsects of the University. It was created to plan long range improvements set to be in place by the mid 1980s.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Access to this collection is unrestricted.

userestrict.head: Copyright

Researchers do not have permission to publish or disseminate material from these collections without permission from an archivist and/or the copyright holder.

The researcher assumes full responsibility for conforming to the laws of copyright. acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: All items in this collection were transferred to the University Libraries, M.E. Grenander Department of Special Collections and Archives by the Office of the President.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Preferred citation for this material is as follows: Identification of specific item, series, box, folder, The Task Force for Long Range Planning, 1972-1973. M.E. Grenander Department of Special Collections and Archives, University Libraries, University at Albany, State University of New York (hereafter referred to as the Task force for Long Range Planning).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection is made up of reports made by the Task Force for Long Range Planning. These were submitted to the University's administration and evaluated. They covered proposed changes for various aspects of the University including admissions, effectiveness by program, faculty treatment, and the quality of life on campus.
